Slavery was like the proverbial elephant in the room for the Founding Fathers. But all of them recognized it to be wrong and wanted gradual abolition to avoid social/familial disruption, at least in in their time. Washington's will provided for freeing his slaves after his wife's death. Jefferson had a strangely ambivalent approach to the question, what with his opposition to slave trade and also opposition to manumission law. Owner of many slaves who worked to build his grand estate at Monticello, he allowed two of his mixed-breed children from cohabitation with Sally Hemings to escape rather than freeing them.
Madison was perhaps the one who articulated his moral/practical crisis with some degree of openness (other than of course the untainted John Adams and the Quaker-abolitionist convert Benjamin Franklin), as is evident from his Federalist Papers (No.54), cited by another correspondent here. In a letter to Lafayette (1826) Madison asserted: 'the two races cannot coexist, both free and equal', and suggested the ultimate solution of external colonization. Interestingly, later on Lincoln who, in his 'House Divided' speech, asserted the opposite that the two races could not 'coexist, permanently half free and half slave', also toyed for some time with the idea of colonization in Liberia. But it was Lincoln's master stroke to confiscate, as a military necessity, the so-called elephant, or 'persons held to service' by the 'property-holding' rebels,

Solid article. Its observations are quite telling. Where traditional access to education used to offer members of the laboring class the opportunity to move into the managerial class, a shift to online university education will tend to limit such upward social and intellectual mobility. The financially well off will still send their offspring to brick and mortar classrooms for that triangulated educational experience. The less financially fortunate will have to settle for the collapsed, measurement and testing environment of the virtual world. Here comes Orwell's "proles". If we were truly committed to access to education as a means of creating whole persons and citizens instead of merely a class of trained employees, we would serious revisit and revamp public education access and funding, and return our society to the enduring idea of the common good.

When Patrick Henry attended the 2nd Virginia Convention at Williamsburg in March 1775 the issue of revolution was far from settled. Colonists were wringing their hands about what to do.

Henry noted in his speech, "...different men often see the same subject in different lights; and, therefore, I hope it will not be thought disrespectful to those gentlemen if, entertaining as I do, opinions of a character very opposite to theirs, I shall speak forth my sentiments freely, and without reserve."

He continued, " ...Mr. President, it is natural to man to indulge in the illusions of hope. We are apt to shut our eyes against a painful truth, and listen to the song of that siren till she transforms us into beasts. ..."

We should heed his counsel.

I, too, have reason to be weary and wary of war. I spent 14 months of my life in a combat infantry company in Vietnam and the result was ugly, and was opposed to and hated the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan that relatives served, and one horribly suffered, in.

But there are bad men in the world who will do bad things and who should be confronted. The world has a history of reluctance to confront evil. Even here at home we did nothing about brutality against Blacks until forced to.

"Well, one likely answer is that he hasn’t heard any of the good news. Think about it: Who would tell him?"

The actual Marxian quotation (and a splendid embodiment of chutzpah it is!), is:

"Well, who you gonna believe, me or your own eyes?!"

As such, we might more aptly ascribe the quotation today *to* such Republicans as Senator Barrasso, who seem to be asking us to take their word on faith, notwithstanding the contrary reality that we're seeing with our own eyes!

Incidentally, while widely attributed to Groucho, the line is actually delivered by *Chico* Marx, in 1933's "Duck Soup" -- although it's in a scene where Chico's character has disguised himself as Groucho's character, so some confusion is understandable.
